facts.text: This is Writ Petition No. 110 of 1964 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 110 of 1964. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforc

facts.text: The petition is a sequel to the judgment in T. Devadasan v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J.-This petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is a sequel

facts.text: Petitioner was Assistant in Grade IV of the Central Secretariat Service.

anchor.surface_text: to the judgment of this Court in T. Devadasan v. Union of India 1 . The petitioner was Assistant in Grade IV of the

facts.text: Next post petitioner could expect was Section Officer Assistant Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: Central Secretariat Service. The next post which the petitioner companyld expect to get was of Section Officer  Assist

facts.text: Recruitment to Section Officer: 50% direct recruitment, 25% promotion via departmental exam by UPSC, 25% seniority cum-fitness.

anchor.surface_text: ant Superintendent . Recruitment to the post of Section Officer is made in the following manner - 50 by direct recruitm

facts.text: In February 1960, UPSC issued notification for limited competitive examination in June 1960 for Section Officers.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1960 the Union Public Service Commission issued a numberification to the effect that a limited companype

facts.text: Notification stated reservation of 12.5% for scheduled castes and 5% for scheduled tribes.

anchor.surface_text: titive examination for promotion to the post of Section Officers would be held in June 1960. The numberification furthe

facts.text: Petitioner sat for the examination and secured 37th position in order of merit.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner sat for this examination and he is said to have secured the 37th position in order of merit. Later, a

facts.text: Press communique stated 48 vacancies expected: 32 reserved for SC/ST, 16 unreserved.

anchor.surface_text: Later, a press companymunique was issued by the Union Public Service Commission in the which it was stated that the

facts.text: UPSC recommended 45 names: 16 unreserved, 29 reserved.

anchor.surface_text: number of vacancies expected to be filled was 48 out of which 32 were reserved for schedule castes and scheduled trib

facts.text: Government made 43 appointments: 15 unreserved, 28 reserved.

anchor.surface_text: es and 16 were unreserved. Eventually however the Union Public Service Commission recommended 45 names for appointme

facts.text: Heavy reservation based on carry forward rule from 1955.

anchor.surface_text: nt, 16 of which were unreserved and 29 were reserved against vacancies for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes. Fi

facts.text: Ministry of Home Affairs resolution dated September 13, 1950 fixed 12% SC and 5% ST without carry forward.

anchor.surface_text: This heavy reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes was made on the basis of the carry forward rule whi

facts.text: In 1952, supplementary instructions issued with carry forward for two years.

anchor.surface_text: According to the resolution of the Ministry of Home Affairs dated September 13, 1950 reservation for scheduled cast

facts.text: 1955 rule changed carry forward: unfilled vacancies carried forward for two years without lapse.

anchor.surface_text: in 1955 however. Government made further change in the carry forward rule and paras. 5  3   and 5  4  of the instruct

facts.text: In Devadasan case, Court struck down 1955 carry forward rule as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Ibis reservation was attacked in the, case of Devadasan 1  and this Court struck down the carry forward rule of 1955

facts.text: Petitioner contends no carry forward rule exists post-Devadasan, only 12.5% SC + 5% ST reservation.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytends that the effect of this Courts judgment in Devadasans case 1  is that there is numbercarr

facts.text: Petitioner alternatively contends 1952 rule also violative of Art. 16.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner further companytends that in view of there being numbercarry forward rule either of 1952 or of 1955

facts.text: Court holds no carry forward rule exists: 1955 struck down, 1952 ceased to exist upon substitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that after the judgment of this Court in Devadasans case 1  there is numbercarry forwa

facts.text: Without carry forward, for 48 vacancies: 6 SC, 3 ST reserved (9 total), 39 unreserved.

anchor.surface_text: Originally it was numberified that the number of vacancies expected were 48. On that basis the reservation for sched

facts.text: For 45 recommended: 6 SC, 3 ST (9 reserved), but adjusted to 43 appointments: 6 SC, 3 ST (9 reserved), 34 unreserved.

anchor.surface_text: Actually however the Public Service Commission recommended only 45 names. On the basis of 45, scheduled castes woul

facts.text: Petitioner secured 37th in unreserved; one ahead went elsewhere, so possibly 36th; but only 34 unreserved slots.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner secured 37th place in the unreserved quota. Out of these 37, one unreserved candidate was recruited

facts.text: Petition fails as petitioner not entitled to appointment.

anchor.surface_text: The petition therefore fails.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Wanchoo, J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen and B. N. Kirpal, for the petitioner. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the respondent

Art. 32 of the Constitution of India

concepts.interpretation: Basis for filing writ petition for enforcement of fundamental rights.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 110 of 1964. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of Ind

anchor.surface_text: Art. 32 of the Constitution is a sequel

concepts.interpretation: Jurisdiction to entertain petition as sequel to previous judgment.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: dgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, J.-This petition under Art. 32 o

anchor.surface_text: Art. 16 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Petitioner contends carry forward rule of 1952 violative of Art. 16; court holds unnecessary to decide as no such rule exists.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: it is submitted that if the carry forward rule of 1952 is still deemed to exist that rule is also bad being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution.

concepts.unlisted_description: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment

anchor.surface_text: This heavy reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes was made on the basis of the carry forward rule which was put into force from 1955.

concepts.interpretation: 1955 rule struck down in Devadasan as unconstitutional; 1952 rule ceased to exist on substitution by 1955 rule; no carry forward rule operative post-Devadasan.

anchor.surface_text: In 1952 however supplementary instructions were issued in this connection... carry forward was only for two years

concepts.interpretation: 1952 instructions provided carry forward for two years after which reservations lapsed; substituted and ceased to exist in 1955.

concepts.unlisted_description: Two-year carry forward of unfilled SC/ST vacancies with lapse thereafter

concepts.interpretation: 1955 modification removed lapse provision, allowing cumulative carry forward; declared unconstitutional in Devadasan.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: early date. In the event of a suitable scheduled caste candidate number being available, a scheduled tribe candidate can be appointed to the reserved

concepts.unlisted_description: Modified carry forward without lapse for more than two years

anchor.surface_text: According to the resolution of the Ministry of Home Affairs dated September 13, 1950 reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes was fixed at 12Â½ and 5 respectively without anything like the carry forward rule.

concepts.interpretation: Fixed quota of 12.5% SC and 5% ST applied year-to-year on vacancies without carry forward; adjustment between SC/ST vacancies permitted via roster if suitable candidates unavailable.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: case 1  therefore is only to strike down, the carry forward rule and it does number affect the year to year reservation for scheduled castes and shed

concepts.unlisted_description: 12.5% for Scheduled Castes, 5% for Scheduled Tribes in recruitment

anchor.surface_text: In the event of a suitable scheduled caste candidate not being available, a scheduled tribe candidate can be appointed to the reserved vacancy and vice versa subject to adjustment in the subsequent point. of the roster.

concepts.interpretation: Permits interchange of SC/ST reserved vacancies subject to roster adjustment; unaffected by striking down of carry forward rule.

issues.text: whether the carry forward rule of 1952 can still be said to exist

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore that arises is whether the carry forward rule of 1952 can still be said to exist.

issues.text: whether the carry forward rule of 1952, if it still exists is bad for the same reasons as the carry forward rule of 1955, as held by this Court in Devadasans case

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the carry forward rule of 1952, if it still exists is bad for the same reasons as the carry forward rule of 1955, as held by this Court in Devadasans case 1 .

issues.text: whether the petitioner would be entitled to appointment even if the carry forward rule of 1952 does not exist

anchor.surface_text: The last question is whether the petitioner would be entitled to appointment even if the carry forward rule of 1952 does number exist.

issues.text: if the carry forward rule of 1952 is still deemed to exist that rule is also bad being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative it is submitted that if the carry forward rule of 1952 is still deemed to exist that rule is also bad being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Effect of Devadasan judgment is that there is no carry forward rule in existence as the 1955 rule was struck down and the 1952 rule ceased to exist by substitution.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner contends that the effect of this Courts judgment in Devadasans case 1  is that there is no carry forward rule in existence as the 1955 carry forward rule was struck down by this Court and the 1952 rule had ceased to exist by the substitution made by the Government of India in 1955.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hall first companysider the question whether the carry forward rule of 1952 still exists. It is true that in Devadasans case 1 , the final order of th

arguments.claim: Without carry forward rule, Government could only reserve 12.5% for SC and 5% for ST in 1960 examination.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner further contends that in view of there being no carry forward rule either of 1952 or of 1955 after the judgment of this Court in Devadasans case 1  all that the Government of India could do in the matter of reservation for the examination conducted in 1960 was to reserve 12 1/2 % of the vacancies for scheduled castes and 5% for scheduled tribes.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce versa, The effect of the judgment in Devadasans case 1  therefore is only to strike down, the carry forward rule and it does number affect the year

arguments.claim: If carry forward rule of 1952 still exists, it is violative of Article 16 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative it is submitted that if the carry forward rule of 1952 is still deemed to exist that rule is also bad being violative of Art. 16 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Petitioner entitled to appointment and excess SC/ST appointments over 17.5% should be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner finally contends that the carry forward rules of 1952 and 1955 being out of this way and the only reservation that was possible in the examination of 1960 being 12 1/2 % for scheduled castes and 5% for scheduled tribes, he was entitled to be appointed on that basis.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y 45 names. On the basis of 45, scheduled castes would be entitled to 5.625 vacancies  i.e. 6 vacancies  while scheduled tribes would be entitled to 2

arguments.claim: Even if carry forward rule of 1952 non-existent, petitioner not entitled to appointment due to merit position.

anchor.surface_text: The application is opposed on behalf of the Union of India and the main contention urged is that even if the carry forward rule of 1952 is deemed to be non-existent because it was substituted by the carry forward rule of 1955, the petitioner would not be entitled to be appointed in any case in view of the position he had secured in the examination.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y 45 names. On the basis of 45, scheduled castes would be entitled to 5.625 vacancies  i.e. 6 vacancies  while scheduled tribes would be entitled to 2

arguments.claim: Carry forward rule of 1952 does not exist as it was substituted by 1955 rule.

anchor.surface_text: The carry forward rule of 1952 was substituted by the carry forward rule of 1955. On this substitution the carry forward rule of 1952 clearly ceased to exist because its place was taken by the carry forward rule of 1955.

arguments.claim: Striking down 1955 rule does not revive ceased 1952 rule.

anchor.surface_text: When therefore this Court struck down the carry forward rule as modified in 1955 that did not mean that the carry forward rule of 1952 which had already ceased to exist... could revive.

arguments.claim: Devadasan only struck down carry forward rule, not basic 12.5% SC and 5% ST reservation or roster adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: But it must be made clear that the judgment of this Court in Devadasans case 1  is only concerned with that part of the instructions of the Government of India which deal with the carry forward rule it does not in any way touch the reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes at 12 1/2 and 5 respectively nor does it touch the filling up of scheduled tribes vacancies by scheduled caste candidates...

arguments.claim: Unnecessary to decide constitutionality of 1952 rule as it no longer exists.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it is unnecessary to consider whether the carry forward rule of 1952 would be unconstitutional, for that rule no longer exists.

arguments.claim: Without carry forward, only 9 reserved (6 SC + 3 ST) out of 43 appointments, 34 unreserved; petitioner at 36th/37th not entitled.

anchor.surface_text: Originally it was notified that the number of vacancies expected were 48. On that basis the reservation for scheduled castes would be 6 and for scheduled tribes would be 2.4... The petitioner however was 36th on the unreserved quota and therefore even on the basis of there being no carry forward rule only 34 candidates would be appointed from the unreserved quota and the petitioner being 36th on his own showing can not claim appointment.

holdings.text: after the judgment of this Court in Devadasan's case there is no carry forward rule at all, for the carry forward rule of 1955 was struck down by this Court while the carry forward rule of 1952 had ceased to exist when the Government of India substituted the carry forward rule of 1955 in its place

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that after the judgment of this Court in Devadasans case 1  there is no carry forward rule at all, for the carry forward rule of 1955 was struck down by this Court while the carry forward rule of 1952 had ceased to exist when the Government of India substituted the carry forward rule of 1955 in its place.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The 1952 carry forward rule was substituted and ceased to exist upon introduction of the 1955 rule; striking down the 1955 rule does not revive the prior rule.

holdings.text: the judgment of this Court in Devadasan's case is only concerned with that part of the instructions of the Government of India which deal with the carry forward rule it does not in any way touch the reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes at 12 1/2 and 5 respectively nor does it touch the filling up of scheduled tribes vacancies by scheduled caste candidates where sufficient number of scheduled tribes are not available in a particular year or vice versa

anchor.surface_text: But it must be made clear that the judgment of this Court in Devadasans case 1  is only concerned with that part of the instructions of the Government of India which deal with the carry forward rule it does not in any way touch the reservation for scheduled castes and scheduled tribes at 12 1/2 and 5 respectively nor does it touch the filling up of scheduled tribes vacancies by scheduled caste candidates where sufficient number of scheduled tribes are not available in a particular year or vice versa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Devadasan judgment limited to carry forward rule; basic year-to-year reservations and SC/ST roster adjustments between castes/tribes unaffected.

holdings.text: it is unnecessary to consider whether the carry forward rule of 1952 would be unconstitutional, for that rule no longer exists

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it is unnecessary to consider whether the carry forward rule of 1952 would be unconstitutional, for that rule no longer exists.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since 1952 rule does not exist post-substitution and Devadasan, no need to assess its constitutionality under Article 16.

holdings.text: even on the basis of there being no carry forward rule only 34 candidates would be appointed from the unreserved quota and the petitioner being 36th on his own showing can not claim appointment

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner however was 36th on the unreserved quota and therefore even on the basis of there being no carry forward rule only 34 candidates would be appointed from the unreserved quota and the petitioner being 36th on his own showing can not claim appointment. The petition therefore fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For 43 appointments without carry forward: 6 SC + 3 ST reserved (total 9), 34 unreserved; petitioner ranked 36th/37th in unreserved merit list.
